title: CTRL0000923620 - Transcribed Interview of Nicholas DeCarlo, (October 4, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 4:01 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a transcribed interview of Mr. Nicholas Decarlo, conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
And, at this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your
Thank you very much, Mr. Decarlo.
So this will be a staff-led deposition, and if members join -- I don't see any on the
Webex right now, but if any of them join, they may also ask questions.
and I'm an investigative counsel with the select
With me in the room is
the time, I do not see any other staff on the Webex, but I will announce them if they join
And, at this time, could counsel please state your name for the record?
practice in Washington, D.C., and I'm counsel for Mr. Decarlo.
So there is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview, so, Mr.
Decarlo, please wait until each question is completed before you begin your response,
and we'll try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographers cannot record us talking over each other, especially in this
virtual environment, so we'll do our best not to talk over one another.
reporters also cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head, so it's
important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
And we ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If the question is not clear -- and that can happen -- please just ask for clarification.
if you do not know the answer, please simply say so.
Does that all make sense to you?
And I'm just going to go over a couple more things before
So, first, it is important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
any time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private, please let us know,
and we will take a break so you can have that conversation with Mr. Feitel.
And, second, this interview is not under oath, but, because this is a formal
congressional investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the
same as if you were speaking with the FBI or DOJ.
false information to Congress, and, for this interview, providing false statements could
result in criminal penalties for those false statements.
It is unlawful to deliberately provide
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what we discuss
prosecutor or judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us, including the
But, also, it is our House deposition rules that you cannot record this interview.
So can you please confirm, Mr. Decarlo, that you are not recording this interview?
I confirm I'm not recording this interview.
The select committee is separate and independent from the Department of
the select committee in its investigation.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions, and the DOJ is not a partner of
The select committee also is not a party to your criminal case, and it is not
agreeing to submit anything on your behalf to the judge.
representation whether, if you tell the judge you met with us, that the judge will be more
And, lastly, we are not going to share the substance of what you said with the
Department of Justice prior to your sentencing, but there are a couple of possible
thought law enforcement was unaware of or if we had reason to believe that you lied
during this interview, then we would be obligated to tell the Department of Justice or
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, just understand that that may
prompt questions from the judge about what you said and whether it is consistent with
your prior statements and acceptances of responsibilities, and, if the judge starts asking
questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
So, all that being said, just, you know, let us know if you need any breaks as we're
going along, or, as I said, if you'd like to discuss anything with Mr. Feitel, we are happy to
So any questions before we get started on all of that?
So we'll start with just some basic background information, Mr. Decarlo.
I grew up in Phoenix, Arizona.
And how long did you live in Phoenix?
And where do you live now?
Have you lived in Tennessee for most of your adult life, then?
Before this, I lived in Fort Worth.
Do you have any military or law enforcement service in your
Last week was when it ended.
What was your last prior career or job?
I've been employed for the last 4 months as
a service advisor for Christian Brothers Automotive.
And that's in Tennessee, I assume?
What's the -- is the name of it "Murder the Media"?
And are you still working with Murder the Media?
What is your role with the organization?
I do live shows, occasional posts, and prerecorded content.
Does Justin Dunn have, like, on online handle or some alternate pseudonym
So what is your -- you have a logo on the screen, MT Media.
And how long have you been with Murder the Media?
Are you someone who -- did you, like, found this company or --
Yeah, he has a few of them.
Off the top of my head, Viii Nomerly.
So I think we'll probably get into some of these chats later,
but when there's a Viii Nomerly in your chat, you Telegram messages, that is Mr. Justin
Do you receive income from MT Media?
Give us an approximate, how much you receive per year.
Is that advertisements mostly or donations?
And just another quick background question.
Have you ever worked for any
government agency -- Federal, State, local -- in the past?
Now, Mr. Decarlo, are you now or have you ever been a Proud Boy?

were you in a certain chapter of the Proud Boys?
I was just kind of there.

So then, I guess, tell us a little bit of why you decided to join the

It was just sort of a, you

Like, what were you guys gathering to do?
Really just, like, build each other up as men, you know?

There were a few chapters in the State.

I didn't mean to cut you off.
president, but they really didn't organize anything outside of just, you know, where we'd

It was a little political, but, I mean, it was -- it wasn't -- it wasn't, like, our

brought in when you decided to leave?

joined, it was three general rules.

you know, basically things -- they started trying to label everybody in the group as, like,

himself or other people down the line who were adding these tenets?
I think it was a combination of both.
they gained attention by going to rallies and stuff, and they sort of fed on that and added

to, you know, rallies and whatnot.

like, the internet fame from it?
It's, they saw they got attention,
they saw they got, you know, on viral videos and everything and -- yeah.
No, that's exactly what it is.

And that was mostly Republican politics?

more like the majority of the people that started to join, they wanted to become political

And I wasn't really --1 didn't join for that reason.
Did you notice a -- how did you notice this besides the tenets?
Was there a change in, sort of, the conversations that were being had at these meetings
Well, it wasn't the meetings that I would go to.
But, yeah, it was sort of, like -- what's the word I'm looking

I'm going to list a couple Proud Boys and ask if you know them.
And how do you know him?
I've met him through friends of friends.
Were these at Proud Boy meet-ups?
So then how did you meet him, or --

Once in 2020 and then one or two times before that.
I mean, I've made friends in the group, you know.
I just didn't feel like being, you know, part of that organization or
So I know you just said you knew Mr. Nordean.
Was an elder at that point?
Honestly, I don't recall who was and who wasn't.

ever really in it; he was just sort of around it to gain attention.

don't recall hanging out with him in Texas.

fun of me for being a luddite.

there, no one's really voted for.
